southern California. Exercises that she developed help to improve blood
circulation and oxygenation, respiration and blood pressure, as well as to
improve balance, strength and endurance in four sessions  or an all day
session. I have adapted her program to include activities that expand
possibilities for the future of women’s lives. Activities like story telling
and riding to music explore emotionally and spiritually an expanded
understanding of the participant’s larger life. 
What We Need & What You Get
We got started with two participants
last September with the help of over 60 volunteers who worked throughout the
summer to make the pilot program a reality. Now we need your help to expand the
program to serve 36 women. If we exceed our goal, your contributions will fund
the creation of training materials for establishing the program in other parts
of the world. And we’ll add a second horse to the program for further expansion
and to share the work when Mystic needs a break.
This year we anticipate 4 sessions of
Riding Beyond June through September and two all day sessions serving a total
of 36 women for this year. Our budget for this program for the year is nearly
$29,000, covering horse and equipment expenses, training of volunteers, program
promotion, insurance, facility rental, administration and professional fees.
 Your tax deductible gift, whether it’s $5 or more, can help make Riding Beyond a
reality.  Regardless of your ability to give money, your best gift to
Riding Beyond is for you to share our campaign far and wide: to breast cancer
survivors, their friends and families and to people who are horse
enthusiasts. 
Everyone who gives to the campaign
will receive a high resolution, electronic poster called Advice from Mystic
with a beautiful image by professional photographer Cornelius Matteo who has contributed his extraordinary work to Riding Beyond as seen throughout our campaign, as well
as periodic updates in the form of stories and photos throughout the four
months that we are in session. If you give $1000 or more, I will take you or a
friend on a half day trail ride on the Pacific Crest Trail, among the best
trail riding available anywhere in the world. We’ll be posting more perks over
the coming weeks, so check back with us. The greatest perk, though, is your
satisfaction in helping to establish a program that attends to the needs of so
many women. The Impact
Most of the women who have gone
through radiation and chemotherapy treatment have ongoing issues to deal with,
like these:


They need physical and emotional revitalization. 


Vital functions have been impaired,
like digestion, respiration (shallow breathing) and rapid heart rate.


Self image is impacted by surgery and
chemotherapy and radiation treatment. 


Tactile defensiveness: not enjoying
touch or being touched. 


A need to reconnect to her body and
to others. 


Physical weakness. 


Here is how Riding Beyond helps.
TOUCH
The act of touching a beautiful,
calm, and sensitive large animal like a horse who responds with sighs and other
signs of enjoyment opens participants to the wonder and power of touch in a
non-threatening and potent environment. This experience is an important first step in
Riding Beyond. 
LYING ON THE HORSE
Lying on the back of a horse for 60
seconds or longer, face-down on the horse’s rump, activates the part of the
vagus nerve which runs along the front of the body.  Several
things occur with this exercise.  There is a gentle compression of the
diaphragm and lungs.  There is an energetic connection between the horse’s
body and the woman’s body so that respiration and heart rate entrain with the
slower rates of the horse.  This effect has been measured in scientific
research:
Recent studies conducted by the
Institute of HeartMath provide a clue to explain the bidirectional
"healing" that happens when we are near horses. According to
researchers, the heart has a larger electromagnetic field and higher level of
intelligence than the brain: A magnetometer can measure the heart's energy
field radiating up to 8 to 10 feet around the human body. While this is
certainly significant it is perhaps more impressive that the electromagnetic
field projected by the horse's heart is five times larger than the human one
(imagine a sphere-shaped field that completely surrounds you). The horse's
electromagnetic field is also stronger than ours and can actually directly
influence our own heart rhythm.
Horses are also likely to have what
science has identified as a "coherent" heart rhythm (heart rate
pattern) which explains why we may "feel better" when we are around
them. . . .studies have found that a coherent heart pattern or HRV is a robust
measure of well-being and consistent with emotional states of calm and
joy--that is, we exhibit such patterns when we feel positive emotions.
A coherent heart pattern is
indicative of a system that can recover and adjust to stressful situations very
efficiently. Often times, we only need to be in a horse’s presence to feel a
sense of wellness and peace. In fact, research shows that people experience
many physiological benefits while interacting with horses, including lowered
blood pressure and heart rate, increased levels of beta-endorphins
(neurotransmitters that serve as pain suppressors), decreased stress levels,
reduced feelings of anger, hostility, tension and anxiety, improved social
functioning; and increased feelings of empowerment, trust, patience and
self-efficacy.
Often upon rising up from the prone
position, a woman is able to take a deep, abdominal breath for the first time
in months. Measurements of heart rate before and after this exercise show
measurable improvements in both heart rate and oxygen levels in the
blood. 
Since the vagus nerve controls the
autonomic nervous system, improvements in digestion and other functions are benefitted,
as well. 
Participants practice lying on a
horse’s back at the beginning of each session by mounting a specially
constructed barrel horse. 
SYNCHRONIZED MOVEMENT TO MUSIC
Initially, participants walk side by
side with the horse and then later on the back of the horse, in synchrony with
inspiring music.  This promotes a deep level of relaxation and
reconnection with the horse and the others walking along.  There is often
an experience of ecstasy that goes beyond words. 
MIND/BRAIN EXERCISES
Exercises develop the use of the
imagination and, more, the imaginal body or the muscular imagination, to
vividly focus and to align themselves with their higher purpose.  These
exercises take advantage of neural plasticity and make available to the participant
parts of their brains previously untapped. 
EXPLORING THE LARGER LIFE 
A fundamental purpose of Riding
Beyond is to explore the threads of the larger patterns of our lives,
reconfiguring one’s challenges in the context of a larger destiny.  This
is accomplished through fictional and true life story telling, creative word
play and reading of poetry and other relevant inspirational passages. 
STRENGTH AND BALANCE
Riding a horse at a walk and
responding to the complex movement, which is side to side, back and forth and
rotational, stimulates nerves and muscles to increase strength and improve
balance and proprioception. 
BONDING
One of the most powerful experiences
for all involved is the bonding between the horse and the people, participants
and volunteers alike. Riding Beyond is full of heart-opening moments. As one
participant remarked with wonder; “I discovered I was in for a profound healing
of the heart.”  
HOW RIDING BEYOND CAME TO BE
After a career of teaching riding and
training horses, I turned over 25 years ago to therapeutic riding because I
felt that there were so many larger benefits to the horse human relationship
that went beyond competition and I wanted to offer these benefits to a larger
audience. 
I established the Saddle Light Center
in San Antonio Texas and later reopened the HOPE Equestrian Center in the Rogue
Valley.  I worked with at-risk teens in a summer program which showed them
how the trials and tribulations of their lives were in actuality the
whisperings of their destiny calling them on their own hero’s journey.  I
wrote a book about it: Riding Into Your Mythic Life: Transformational
Adventures with the Horse. 
For the past ten years I have taught
Journey Horse, here and in Australia, which are modern day vision quests with
horses, as well as other seminars for professionals in equine assisted
activities and therapies. About a year ago I began to yearn to offer something
of my work to my home community here in the Rogue Valley.
Last spring I was presenting my work
at Prescott Best Practices conference and I heard about a remarkable program in
southern California established 7 years ago.  There was a bit of magic
about it, because I met Catherine Hand briefly when we sat next to one another
at the opening address. She invited me to her presentation, which I probably
would have missed otherwise. At the presentation she told how seven years ago
she was in hospice, dying of damage to her heart and lungs from her radiation
treatment for breast cancer. She had given away her dogs and all but one of her
horses.  One day, she said, she read a book Riding Into Your Mythic Life
and was inspired. It occurred to her that perhaps the story handed her by the
medical profession did not need to be her own story.  (She commented that
the author of that book was somewhere at the conference and to everyone’s
delight I let her know right then that we had already met.)  That day
seven years ago, with the help of a friend she felt inspired to climb onto the
back of her one remaining horse and lay down on the horse’s rump.  Two
days later a hospice nurse asked her what she was doing to be getting better.
 Her rapid heart rate had improved and her oxygenation levels had
increased.  It took her a while to remember that the only thing she’d done
different was to climb on that horse’s back.  After that, she partnered
with a medical professional and pursued her insight, and over the next weeks
she left hospice care, and within the next year she got well and proceeded to
establish the program that she offers in southern California. 
I came home from Arizona inspired to
offer Riding Beyond to my own community. Over 60 people pitched in, helping in
so many different ways.   People and a horse got trained, we gathered or
constructed the equipment we needed, and then we conducted the pilot program in
September. 
PARTICIPANTS IN THE PILOT PROGRAM
SAID
"I came to Riding Beyond with only
the expectation that I would get to know a tiny bit about horses and maybe find
some small happiness for the moment. 
I’d gone through a very difficult
year – a diagnosis of cancer and the loss of my beloved youngest daughter. Joy
was hard to come by. Grief was an every day companion. . . 
I went to the first day of the
program with pretty much no idea whether I’d get bucked off a frisky horse or
have a spontaneous healing like ones I’d heard about. Trish had explained the
program, but with my extremely limited exposure to horses I don’t think
anything really gelled. Well, I was in for one of the most treasured and
healing experiences I’ve had in this rocky road of life. This would be a
healing of the heart.
Mystic’s calm, quiet presence quickly
infused me, and I found myself really falling in love with something in her
that was tangibly intangible. 
I found in the following weeks of the
program that I was constantly bringing up her image in my mind when I felt
stressed or sad or even happy. Just the thought of her would calm my mind and
bring a feeling of contentment, peace, wellbeing. On one occasion I was feeling
some deep angst and restlessness and couldn’t really put my finger on the
cause. I then thought of Mystic, almost automatically, like some people reach
for a sedative. Immediately a huge, huge wave of grief enveloped me. The
release was like the wave of a tsunami and the minutes after were like floating
in an endless quiet sea.
Another time I was praying and
meditating but thoughts kept racing in and out, and grief and sadness and
confusion kept tormenting me. Again my mind automatically went to Mystic and
very surprisingly, in an instant, I became profoundly calm, very quiet, at
peace. Well, I didn’t know what to think of that but hey, I’d take it. And so
went the love affair with the horse, Mystic. I am so grateful.”
“I really appreciate the opportunity
that I had to participate in the pilot program for Riding Beyond.  Each
time I left the ranch after these sessions, I had such a feeling of peace and
well-being (it reminded me that I could feel that way!).  The sessions
included time to share experiences and poems.  The whole team participated
in these discussions which resulted in some interesting conversations and ideas
that I had not thought of previously.
In addition to the health/mind
benefits, this experience helped me to overcome my fear of horses.  Trish
and the volunteers shared their knowledge of horses and were there the entire
time – so I felt safe.  And, of course, the star of the show, Mystic, is
an amazing horse.  She is calm, sweet, and patient.  I enjoyed the
time I spent with Mystic and am now looking forward to taking horseback riding
lessons!
It was an extremely positive
experience that I would highly recommend to others.”
SEVEN MONTHS LATER
“The program
ended but Mystic is a permanent fixture in my life, coming to me in moments of
stress and of joy. I had no idea a horse could do that, no idea. It has
supported me through my ongoing treatment: Mystic is a huge piece of my
well-being. So much had been wiped away by my diagnosis and the death of my
daughter, so many of my assumptions of what life was supposed to be were gone.
Maybe because of that I was able to take what she had to give. I always thought
of horses as big and scary, and I found when I was with her, who she was came
out, a giant presence of love and sweetness. It came into me as someone who
walks beside you when you walk through these kinds of times. It's a pure
relationship without all the baggage with people. She really fills me up.”
VOLUNTEERS SAID
“The individual details of our
stories, we did not share. We did not need to know. By sensing together we
created a place to cultivate reverence, awe, grace, dignity and respect. The
courage to walk with horses, not knowing and being vulnerable, allowed us to
weave together our own story, one of deep connection and belonging. Whether you
are a volunteer or participant, the wisdom and magic of horses exists for you.
Allow it and it will change your life. I am Jenny, a Riding Beyond volunteer
and because I dared to be a part of Riding Beyond, I have grown. Thank you,
Riding Beyond volunteers, participants, and of course the horses. Your courage
has given me great joy.” — Jen Lieber
“Immediately I was awed by the
spirits of the other volunteers, all from different backgrounds  and
experiences yet I felt at home right away. My gifts were acknowledged,
appreciated and cared for. Each person was  assigned a place to be of help
within their comfort level,  no matter their experience with horses or
cancer for that matter. People and animals were held with gentleness, grace and
appreciation. Laughter rang out, a few tears ran down cheeks, warmth exploded
out of our space, (in spite of one very icy Ashland day), chickens cheered us
on and I even got hugged by a horse. What a way to spend a morning. Then we had
the blessing of meeting the participants , brave woman finishing a tough course
of treatment and trusting us to help them take a new step on their journey of
healing. An intuitive horse partner, a trained facilitator and amazing
volunteers. We got to watch the magic unfold. It really doesn’t get any
better. Join us and be inspired.
I can also add: since I am a breast
cancer survivor, I inadvertently received a healing blessing from Mystic, who
took time to get to know me and nuzzled her nose on the exact area I first
found my lump….how’s that for intuitive? She then proceeded to give me a horse
hug , gently wrapping her beautiful neck around my leg and holding me. Guess
she knew we all need love.” —Mary Piper
LARGER MATTERS
Although I have not personally
experienced breast cancer, I have accompanied several friends through their own
treatment, and I have witnessed first-hand the suffering and courage that is
required by women who take this journey.  It is life-changing, challenging
their most intimate sense of self and personal identity. My friends were huge
inspirations to me. 
I believe that women who face breast
cancer are ambassadors of the rise of the feminine in the evolutionary process
that we are all participating in, not the rise of feminism, but the rise of the
unique qualities of the feminine soul for nurturing life and finding
life-giving solutions to problems instead of resorting to warfare and violence.
They have the potential to be those who can pioneer a new way, having gone
through a fire that hones their purpose to laser clarity. 
To have breast cancer is
intrinsically involved in what it takes to overcome enormous challenges, and to
gather resources to separate one's identity as a person from the disease at an
intimate level, to find who they are as strong and creative beings. Breast cancer
can strike at their most intimate sense of self and personal identity. Riding
Beyond offers an experience of their core selves as creative and strong,
keeping them in touch with creativity and strength so that they can claim their
personal possibilities for this larger destiny. They are a keystone species
critical to the unfolding of something new and life-sustaining for our world’s
long-term future. 
DEDICATION
This work is dedicated to those
friends of mine who have met the cancer challenge and other women like them around the world.  
It is also dedicated to the
remarkable horses who have demonstrated their willingness,
wisdom and enthusiasm for engaging with humans for such elegant and effective
healing purposes. 
Along the lines of dedicating this
work, I will be attending a Sundance at the Pine Ridge Reservation in South
Dakota for the summer solstice. Although I have been invited to this sundance
for many years, this is the first time that I feel compelled to attend. It is
held at a wild horse sanctuary, and I intend that four days of dancing and
fasting and praying will anchor and launch the future of Riding Beyond, as well
as benefit our wider stewardship of the earth. 
I believe in the power of the horse
human connection because it’s this kind of bridging between species, partnering
with horses in this case, that is a critical practice for the survival of our
world, a world  where so many bridges between peoples and between us and
our planet desperately need to be forged. 
With our horses, it means making
performance goals secondary to relationship goals, so that winning a blue
ribbon is not nearly so important as being able to listen deeply to the
language of a horse, learning their language and involving  them in our
deep and ongoing life journeys as a teacher and companion.  With our
fellow human beings, it leads us to new ways of living and being, bringing
balance to our lives for healing, finding new ways of leadership that are
essentially collaborative, and implementing what we know about our all being
connected as one world on planet Earth. 

Horses
are associated in our imaginations with grand tales of heroism and adventure,
large movement and beauty. This is their mythic aspect. And by engaging with
horses from that perspective, they introduce us to our own mythic lives and
keep us connected to it, that larger life that we so easily can loose sight of,
the life that’s possible for us.  By pursuing that relationship with a
horse, we can go forth, you might say ride forth into that larger life.  Other Ways You Can Help
Just about everybody knows someone
who has been challenged with breast cancer.  Please share this campaign
with them, their friends and families, so that they can help us bring this
beneficial program to more women. 
Know someone who loves horses?
 Share the campaign with them and maybe they will see new possibilities
for a horse that's in their lives. It's easy when you use the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Sherwood A. Grant and I am a wholistic personal trainer of health and fitness in Chicago, IL.  My mission is to assist others in taking great care of their bodies through well-informed eating decisions.

Over the past 15 years, I have reached thousands of people through my nutritional programs, healthy living programs, group fitness classes, and a product line of nutrients from the earth and its waters.

I am introducing a 28-day Salad and Smoothie (“Sal-smoo”) Challenge to encourage participants to begin each day with a salad and dairy-free smoothie. My goal is to help people discover that they can feel more energized and refreshed when they begin their days by fueling their bodies with natural fruits and vegetation from the earth, instead of meats and dairy products.

This campaign is to help provide awesome prizes that will be raffled off to participants of the Sal-smoo Challenge. The purpose is to reward participants for taking steps to improve their eating habits and lifestyles. A daily point system will be used by participants, which will dictate the prize levels. 

Giving participants a reward for taking steps to improve their lifestyle will be a great incentive. With $500 in funding support, prizes can be awarded in unison with the theme of the challenge, encouraging others to step forward.

What We Need & What You Get

I would like for those participating in the challenge to fund this campaign.  I have set a goal of $500 and 100% of the funds will be used to purchase multiple prizes that will support participants in living a healthy lifestyle.

Prizes will be determined based on the number of participants. The more participants, the better the prizes. Ideally, a top prize would include high-grade blender to promote the easy creation of healthy smoothies.

For those not in the Chicagoland area, if you are a winner your prize will be mailed to you.

The Impact

Through this challenge, participants will be introduced to healthier ways of eating, and the results will inspire them to reconsider how they eat, and potentially influence others around them as well. The goal is to reduce people’s beliefs of “needing” meat, dairy, and caffeine to start each day, and instead try new ways of eating that are kinder to the body.

Other Ways You Can Help

Join the movement on Facebook at

https://www.facebook.com/groups/salsmoo/

•  Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.

•  Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story: Please see it in your heart to help me with relocating for necessary medical care.  I have two very rare brain diseases.  Can't get the proper medical care where I live now.  I need to a teaching hospital that sees conditions like I have.  I served my country until my medical retirerment.  I hope that now my country sees it in their hearts to give back to any disabled vet.
